The router needs to have just one child. Try wrapping the children with a `div` like so - ``` jsx

issue.title: [v4] Match group can't be direct child of router
issue.body:
## Version 4.0.0-2 ## Test Case This works: ```
FOO
} />
BAR
} />
``` This doesn't: ```
FOO
} />
BAR
} /> ``` ## Expected Behavior route matches ## Actual Behavior `Uncaught Invariant Violation: MatchProvider.render(): A valid React element (or null) must be returned. You may have returned undefined, an array or some other invalid object.`

rename.from: MatchProvider.render() fails to return valid react element
rename.to: [v4] MatchProvider.render() fails to return valid react element

issue.title: Add Router content wrapper
issue.body:
Solves #3837 problem

Before: `A valid React element (or null) must be returned`.
After: everything renders ok.

body:
I just run into this, the docs seem to suggest (incorrectly) that multiple children can be there:

https://react-router-website-xvufzcovng.now.sh/quick-start

(also, there is an overflow: hidden on one of the top wrapper elements, so the docs are not scrollable)
This is fixed in #3849. Whenever Ryan can update the site, it'll have a `<div>` wrapper.

Indeed, this isn't obvious at all, especially given the claim that "if you know React you can use React Router". Regular React components don't have this restriction. Any chance it could be lifted, perhaps just by adding the `<div>` automatically if it isn't there?

Another related pitfall: if you have a container component whose render method is merely:

``` javascript
render = () => (this.props.children)
```

you can't put a bunch of `<Match>`s in that component.

This is a surprising deviation from regular React and it's worth documenting IMO.

Anyway, thanks for router v4, the API no longer rubs me the wrong way!

@aaugustin It's definitely a deviation from React's DOM components, which all (I think?) accept multiple children. But it's actually not uncommon for compound components. In fact, there even exists a special method, [`React.Children.only`](https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/top-level-api.html#react.children.only), specifically for the case of compound components that only accept a single child. I'm going to amend the code to use it here so people aren't surprised.
@aaugustin How can you do the props.chidren method you mentioned in v4?

issue.title: [v4] How to use BrowserRouter with multiple DOM subtrees?
issue.body: I have the issue, that I want to use the v4 BrowserRouter with multiple DOM subtrees. We are migrating a legacy app step by step and have to render the main navigation outside of the remaining React app. Till now, it worked quite well to push / pop routes to our history (from context). With v4 this seems no longer possible. Any ideas how to solve it?

issue.title: BrowserRouter requires a child element to contain Match/Miss components
issue.body:
Version: 4.0.0-alpha.6. ```jsx import React from 'react' import {render} from 'react-dom' import {BrowserRouter, Match, Miss} from 'react-router' import HomePage from 'components/home-page' import ErrorPage from 'components/error-page' render( , document.getElementById('root') ) ``` Results in `Uncaught Error: React.Children.only expected to receive a single React element child.`. Containing everything under `BrowserRouter` in a `div` fixes the error: ```jsx
``` The requirement for a containing element is not intuitive. Although most of the examples have this wrapper it is not explained in the docs that it is required, and there is [example code that does not have one and would presumably fail](https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/v4.0.0-alpha.6/website/api/Miss.md#miss).
